snippet: Factions of the movement have hardened, while others are involved in kidnappings, robberies and the opium trade — damaging the Taliban’s efforts to win over the Afghan population.
abstract: Taliban leadership has broken into factions, result of a generational schism; more than 13 years after the war in Afghanistan, many original fighters have aged out of movement and younger fighters today are a mixed bag of idealists and hardened criminals who are involved in kidnappings, robberies and opium trade.

byline.contributor: Ahmad Shakib contributed reporting from Kabul; Niamatullah Karyab from Asadabad, Afghanistan; and Khalid Alokozay from Jalalabad, Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: Factions of the movement have hardened, while others are involved in kidnappings, robberies and the opium trade — damaging the Taliban’s efforts to win over the Afghan population.

headline.main: Unruly Factions Hurt Taliban’s Bid to Capture Afghan Hearts, and Territory
headline.print_headline: Schism Hinders Taliban’s Effort at New Image
